Crown profile on a SS-N-D1-I avalanche that failed during the 12/3-12/4 storm on the north end of the summit ridge on Red Cone. The failure plane was a facet/crust combo buried on 12/1. The slab was 100 ft wide, and the vertical fall was 50 ft. The bed surface was an icy granite slab.
w/ Werner

User.name: Andy Anderson
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We toured up the E aspect of Incline Peak following the general path of the summer trail most of the way before splitting from it around 8,900 to head straight to the summit. The day started calm but by the time we reached the top, wind was picking up and clouds were moving in. Many ski tracks covered the mountain, including in over 30 degree areas with no observed avalanches. Surface hoar from .5-1.5 cm was observed the majority of the trip to the top, with smaller crystals found at low elevation in sun affected areas and larger crystals on upper, wind protected areas. Very little was found in areas affected by wind. Snow was still clinging to branches and no obvious signs of substantial wind transport below treeline was observed. We dug a pit about a quarter of the way up to the summit on a NE aspect in an open stand of trees where falling snow was not a factor. Our ECT had results in the upper part of the snowpack but no reactivity in the November facet layer. Our PST was much more fun, with a clean fracture the length of the column. After the test, we pulled the slab off and it slid as a cohesive unit on to the ground. Confirming our concerns, we stayed on sub-30 degree slopes in the trees for both the ascent and descent.

Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile of N-SS-R3-D2 -O. Crown ranges from 50 to 100cm, is approximately 35m wide connecting around terrain features in steep rocky terrain with sparse trees. It ran approximately 30m downhill into low-angle forest. There are two distinct failure planes. The first is a storm interface from the last 24 hrs. down 35cm. The lower failure plane is down 1m at the top of the faceted snow buried 20221201 by a previous storm.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit was dug in a crown.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Cracking;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
90-95cm depth to ground. About 20 cm of Powder on top, above a firm layer about 5 cm thick, then another 20 cm of soft powder before another 5 cm firm layer then another 20cm of dry soft powder to the ground. Soft powder layers are dry large flakes that are not bonding and are roughly fist firmness. Only good news is that the firm layers aren't THAT firm, about one finger to four fingers in firmness. Multiple ICTs showed failures at both the central and ground-level soft layers. Failures varied from elbow to shoulder, but consistently failed and consistently failed in the same places.
The lower soft and firm layer likely originates from October and the next soft and firm layers from November. Neither will likely solidify anytime soon.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Quick pit dug, crust sandwich is decomposing and healing did not identify all the crusts just one section on profile for all of them.
No wind where the pit was dug, but strong SW winds on the ridge tops.

Full profile. Relatively low density snowpack with three obvious melt freeze crusts. The crust closest to the surface was made up of very thin, visible ice (~2-3mm thick). The second crust was the thickest and most pronounced (~2cms thick). Snow grains below and between these crusts consisted of small to very small faceted grains. Some rounding was observed near the ground.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Avalanche was discovered 2022.12.04 in the late evening. 300' wide, 4-500' vertical distance. Crown face was 2-6' deep. Average 4'. Flanks tapered to 1' on either side. Pit dug in center of path skiers right of the deepest part of the crown face. Bed surface was a mostly brittle MF crust with small NSF above.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 10m cracking coming up through the trees, seemed isolated to the location. Small amount of wind loading observed off a small ridge skiers right in the fan. 100m up there was a 48h+ avalanche sz.2 just below the choke of the couloir. 20m across, 60cm deep, ran 100m terminated mid track. North aspect. Skier triggered a small size 1 soft slab on noted wind loading on the descent. 10cm deep, 5 meters across, ran 10m.

On NE edge of Cottonwood Bowl, heavily wind affected, scoured, exposed rocks.
Rime crust atop snow on NE,E aspect, not found on NW aspect other side of ridge investigated by other members of course.
heavy winds lead me to spend little time poking in snow and writing in the book. sorry for lack of details
Lots of obvious wind slabs noted today.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Upper Silver Fork, ECTX although there was an easy enough shovel shear on small grained facets below the crust @ 117cm from ground on old snow interface. Crust was friable. (GCS of 7). Stability was good, structure was poor. Cold caky snow with cold temperatures.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This is a very weak snow structure. I am concerned about the layers at 55-48 and 44-37. Add a slab on top and we will start seeing avalanches.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: forgot my snow saw and cord. did a "dirty" ECT. Got an ECTN with moderate taps but the upper 40cm of the new snow was not formed into a solid slab at the time, still very light and only semiconsolidated. LOTS of whumpfing during the day touring.

Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Test Pit, top of camels back. Objective: Investigate wind loading along the ridge. Rocks on the ridge impacted the CT results. First test column was shallower than the second due to a rock at the base, resulting in potentially increased instability and weaker layers.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Cracking; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: New snow skied upside down. 48 hr snowfall ~40cm. Propagation in pit below first crust in crust-facet sandwich. Extensive cracking on E-SE-S aspects. Collapsing on all aspects at lower elevations. This storm doubled the snowpack on S aspects.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: variable winds at pit location. Baseline profile ahead of next loading event beginning today. Near surface facets primary concern for future instability.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 206 and I did a pit before the forecasted storm to look at layers. With several weeks without snow, the snowpack is fairly cohesive. There is a melt freeze crust layer near the bottom of the snowpack (3cm) that is a concern, faceting underneath this layer could mean we have stability problems all the way to the ground.
Three weeks of cold and dry conditions.
Sheltered opening in flat treed meadow.
The layer at the ground below the rain crust is interrupted and spanned intermittently by talus on this rocky slope. Difficult to tell if there is continuity in the basal structure across the slope.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ski conditions were very poor, bullet hard icy wind slab to breakable crust. Variable. Forgot ECT cord and attempted to perform one with a shovel and a snow saw but had it break on the problem layer as i was digging behind the column.
